course_title: Basis for Even Sounding Bow Strokes (Demo)
course_content:
Highlights

  • Developing longer bow strokes.
  • Maintaining even sounding bow strokes.
  • Intonation in G Major and D Major.
  • Practicing smoothening the shifts.

Description

With this violin method you are able to experience Scorewind's didactic approach to music for free! We hope you apreciate the "step by step" model we have developed. If so, we welcome you to enroll in the other music methods we have available for you. Have fun! Dancla is well known for his melodic approach to teaching violin technique. This course is prepared for players who have a basic understanding on how to read notes. Both the exercises prepared for the end goal piece and the piece itself must be played with calm, soft sounding and even bow strokes. Since what is demanded from the left hand is not extremely challenging, there is space for focusing on this peculiar quality in this course. After step by step exercises picked to guide the player to the end result, the piece itself gets so much easier to learn!

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Mobility of 2nd finger. (to switch between 1-23 / 12-3 hand positions)
  • Proficiency in maintaining stable tempo.
  • (optional): proficiency in using 4th finger.

What's next

Next course: Get Better at String Crossing Melodiously
course_short_description: With this violin method you are able to experience Scorewind's didactic approach to music for free! We hope you apreciate the "step by step" model we have developed. If so, we welcome you to enroll in the other music methods we have available for you. Have fun!

lessons.lesson_content:
With this violin method you are able to experience Scorewind's didactic approach to music for free! We hope you apreciate the "step by step" model we have developed. If so, we welcome you to enroll in the other music methods we have available for you. Have fun!

Dancla is well known for his melodic approach to teaching violin technique. This course is prepared for players who have a basic understanding on how to read notes. Both the exercises prepared for the end goal piece and the piece itself must be played with calm, soft sounding and even bow strokes. Since what is demanded from the left hand is not extremely challenging, there is space for focusing on this peculiar quality in this course. After step by step exercises picked to guide the player to the end result, the piece itself gets so much easier to learn!

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Open String Playing – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content: Playing the open strings with as long of a bow stroke as possible is very helpful as a warm up exercise. At this point a beginner must not force their muscles to go all the way to the end or start right at the frog. These areas that may be tough to control will get easier within a week or two. Pay attention to tilting the bow towards the frog and widening the point of contact by straightening it towards the tip.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12127/3711 Bow Workout - Open String Playing.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G major scale starting on D string – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

G Major scale in this octave is slightly more complicated than the one in the lower octave due to the change of placement of the 1st finger. The learner must keep the 1st and 2nd fingers very close to each other and play the 1st finger in a way that it gets “resolved” on the second finger.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12126/3712 12126 G Major Scale Starting On D String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12126/3712 G major scale starting on D string.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G major Arpeggios and inversions starting on D string – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Learners can focus on the parallel movements of the fingers in this arpeggio. It is also essential to prepare the finger position of the next note while playing the current note. This way of thinking can apply to the string crossings as well.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12176/3652 12176 G Major Arpeggios Starting On D String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12176/3652 G major Arpeggios and inversions starting on D string.xml

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Scale – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

D Major follows the "1-23" finger pattern in the middle strings which is why it is often used as one of the first scales to start playing the violin. On the way up while playing the 3rd finger the player can prepare the elbows for the next string’s position, and on the way down the open string can be used for the same purpose.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12189/3636 D Major Scale.xml

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Arpeggios and Inversions – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Arpeggios are perfect workouts for fingers to gain autonomy, meaning braking the step by step pattern and act individually within larger intervals. To place the 2nd correctly after open string, one can “imagine” to place the 1st finger and then place the 2nd finger accordingly.

While playing the D Major arpeggio, players should be aware of the diagonal relation between the 2nd and the 3rd finger. This will help to play in tune in the future by associating notes not only to other notes on the same string but to notes that are on the other strings
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12175/3653 D Major Arpeggios and Inversions.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – G Major Fingering – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Exercises

When there is a passage with a repetitive note, the fingers must stay near the string as much as possible for the replacement to be as effortless and rapid as possible. At slow tempos the left hand fingers can “hammer” on the strings as well.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12125/3713 12125 Left Hand Workout - G Major Fingering Exercise.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12125/3713 Left Hand Workout - G Major Fingering Exercise.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – Step by step 3rd and 4th fingers – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise should first played as third finger and open string for the ear to get used to the sound. In the second round the 4th finger can be introduced if it is not too much of a muscle effort at this point. Pressing the pinky with a round manner is not the priority. Fingers can be put on the fingerboard rather flatly to not over work the muscles. A firm press on the pinky does not require too much pressure so keep in mind the trick of "touching the string to the wood" instead of "pressing down deeply".
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12170/3659 12170 Left Hand Workout - Step By Step 3Rd And 4Th Fingers.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12170/3659 Left Hand Workout - Step by step 3rd and 4th fingers.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – String Crossing 1 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content: When crossing between strings, the player can prepare the new angle through the right elbow by the end of the current note. Adapting to the position of the “new” string before playing it makes the string crosses as smooth as possible. Same rule applies to the left elbow when playing notes on the strings.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12169/3661 Bow Workout - String Crossing 1.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Broken 3rds – D Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise for bettering the broken 3rds on the violin must be played very carefully and only after playing the D Major itself is an achievable task. Although it might seem confusing in the beginning, this pattern is very often used in classical music, so getting to used to it will help develop vocabulary for the future, and make learning other pieces a lot easier!
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12168/3662 Broken 3rds - D Major.xml

course_title: Become Better at Long Lasting 8th Note Phrases
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing chromatic crescending lines
  • Playing long lasting eight note runs.
  • Learning to shift from long strokes to short strokes rapidly.
  • Chromatic intonation control.

Description

This step-by-step guide prepares you to perform the Etude No. 8 from Dancla's Op. 84, 36 Melodic Studies book. The piece is played around the keys C Major and of course its relative minor A Minor, which is why the course contains exercises to make these tonalities familiar to your left hand. Pro Tip: When playing the goal piece at the end of the course make sure to breath in and out regularly!

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Mobility of 2nd and 3rd fingers.
  • Proficiency in using 4th finger.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight notes.

What's next

Next course: First Step Towards Rhythmic Challenges
course_short_description: This step-by-step guide prepares you to perform the Etude No. 8 from Dancla's Op. 84, 36 Melodic Studies book. This course contains exercises to make the C major and A minor tonalities familiar to your left hand.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Become Better at Long Lasting 8th Note Phrases’
lessons.lesson_content: This step-by-step guide prepares you to perform the Etude No. 8 from Dancla's Op. 84, 36 Melodic Studies book. The piece is played around the keys C Major and of course its relative minor A Minor, which is why the course contains exercises to make these tonalities familiar to your left hand. Pro Tip: When playing the goal piece at the end of the course make sure to breath in and out regularly!

lessons.lesson_title: A Minor Melodic Scale starting on A string – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing a melodic scale, the player must be very careful about the 6th and 7th notes of the scale since they will be altering between directions. This is highly used in classical music since it keeps the tonality minor and the harmonic tension within melody is distributed evenly.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12183/3643 12183 A Minor Melodic Scale Starting on A String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12183/3643 A Minor Melodic Scale starting on A string.xml

lessons.lesson_title: A Minor Melodic Scale starting on G string – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Lower octave of the A minor melodic scale needs extended 3rd finger position on the D string. In slow tempo practice this note can be played with the 4th finger instead of the 3rd but in faster tempos it would not be as practical unless the tonic (A) is going to be played on the open string.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12182/3644 12182 A Minor Melodic Scale Starting on G String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12182/3644 A Minor Melodic Scale starting on G string.xml

lessons.lesson_title: A Minor Arpeggio and Inversions – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

For beginners, arpeggios of minor scales are slightly harder than the major ones. In this situation the player should be aware that there will be a diagonal and large gap between the 2nd and 3rd finger in the 1st inversion and 2nd and 1st finger in the 2nd inversion.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12173/3655 A Minor Arpeggio and Inversions.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – Speeding up Fingers (A minor melodic) – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When playing this exercise learners must remember that the bow stroke is a simple long bow stroke and keep the left hand fingers as round as possible for precision of timing the 8th notes. Although hammering each note may not be necessary it can be useful to gain strength.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12153/3681 12153 Left Hand Workout Speed up Finger A Minor Mel.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12153/3681 Left Hand Workout - Speeding up Fingers (A minor melodic).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Intonation Workout – B half diminished chord – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Half diminished chords are few of the chords that the fingers are not placed entirely parallel to each other between the strings. Pay attention to the 1st finger; from one string to the other it will shift diagonally. For fine-tuning most beginners must exaggerate this difference.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12152/3682 12152 Intonation Workout B Half Diminished Chord.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12152/3682 Intonation Workout - B half diminished chord.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Broken 3rds – C Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Broken 3rds are a big part of classical music vocabulary. While playing them slow; preparing the string change from both elbows can help the learner to speed up. In faster tempos the elbows should stand in a middle zone between two strings. Focus on breathing in and out regularly while playing this exercise!
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12151/3683 Broken 3rds - C Major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Chromatism Workout – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise is not meant to sound nice! :) While practicing chromatic passages it is important to not slide on the string with full pressure. Finger numbers can alter from one method to the other, but it is mostly safe to play the note with the common 1st position finger that gets together with it. Example; C on the G string is played with the 3rd finger, doesn't matter if it is sharp or not; or B on th G string is played with the 2nd finger, so both flat and natural B will be played with the 2nd finger.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12150/3684 Case Specific - Chromatism Workout.xml

course_content:
Highlights

  • Learn how to treat homophonic voicing.
  • Dynamic range control.
  • Precision in playing various notes at the same time.
  • Focus on arpeggio technique.

Description

This step by step method will help you practice an etude by Mauro Giuliani. In the first part of his etude you will work on homophonic voicing, and the challenges there include the precision of playing them exactly at the same time and with a balanced intensity. On the second part, the intervals become wider, allowing space for an arpeggiated acompaniment technique for the right hand, from which the middle line should be played with lower volume than the singing melody and the bass line.

Requirement

  • Completion of course: ‘Introduction to Chords and Arpeggios’.
  • Novice level of score reading ability.
  • Novice experience in one voice treatment and playing.
  • Familiar with essential beginner chords (Check 'Introduction to Chords and Arpeggios' otherwise).
  • Beginner level in left hand vertical finger extension.
  • Beginner level in right hand arpeggiation.

What's next

Next course: Practice the "Feeling in Three"
course_short_description: This step by step method will help you practice an etude by Mauro Giuliani. In the first part of his etude you will work on homophonic voicing, and on the second part, you will practice wider intervals together with an arpeggiated acompaniment technique for the right hand.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Classical Homophony and Arpeggiation”
lessons.lesson_content: This step by step method will help you practice an etude by Mauro Giuliani. In the first part of his etude you will work on homophonic voicing, and the challenges there include the precision of playing them exactly at the same time and with a balanced intensity. On the second part, the intervals become wider, allowing space for an arpeggiated acompaniment technique for the right hand, from which the middle line should be played with lower volume than the singing melody and the bass line.

lessons.lesson_title: 3/4 Count With 6ths – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
In this exercise you will be practicing two things, parallel 6ths and the feeling of the ternary pulse. Remember to place the weight on the first beat of each bar. Finding the right place for your left elbow will help you play throught the various vertical extensions.

by ScoreWind Teachers
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13545/3759 34 Count With 6ths.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Arpeggio Technique for the Right Hand
lessons.lesson_content:
In this step you will focus on the arpeggiated technique of accompaniment. Both melody and harmony are integrated in a right hand arpeggiated fingering combination. Try reaching the strings by moving the place of your hand rather than stretching your fingers to reach to each string.

by ScoreWind Teachers
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13546/3760 Arpeggio Technique Exercise 4.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Open Broken Thirds in p-m-i Arpeggio – All Available Notes in 1st Position (C Major) – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise will help you to get familiar with the technical challenges over the vertical finger extensions existing in this type of intervals. Make sure to feel comfortable playing them, because they often appear throughout the music of this era.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12101/12101 3761 Open Thirds in p-m-i Arpeggio - All Available Notes in 1st Position (C Major).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12101/3761 Open Thirds in p-m-i Arpeggio - All Available Notes in 1st Position (C Major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Close Broken Thirds in C Major – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Close thirds do not require large finger extensions, as the open thirds usually do, but they often bring uncomfortable finger placement, and challenging finger independence for the left hand. Practice carefully this exercise and the thirds of the music piece will become easier for you.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12100/12100 3762 Close Broken Thirds in C Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12100/3762 Close Broken Thirds in C Major.xml

course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing vibrato on long notes
  • (Optional): playing passages on 3rd position.
  • Switching between wide spread musical phrases and staccato 8th note runs.

Description

This step-by-step guide is planned to help players execute a 3/4 piece that has two very contrasting parts, one that is very lineal and melodic, other that is relatively fast and to be played with a very active attitude. As well as that, the end goal piece have two alternatives fingerings to perform, one on 1st position and the other that includes 3rd position. We recommend the player to first focus on playing the entire piece on 1st position. Only after this goal is reached, the learners can move on to the next challenge, which is to use the fingerings indicated on the score.

Requirement

  • Novice experience in executing staccato technique.
  • Proficiency in 3/4 time signature.
  • Mobility of 2nd finger.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.
  • (Optional): Novice experience in position shifting.

What's next

Next course: Get Better at Slurred String Changes
course_short_description: This step-by-step guide is planned to help players execute a 3/4 piece that has two very contrasting parts, one that is very lineal and melodic, other that is relatively fast and to be played with a very active attitude.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Contrasting Musical Ideas’
lessons.lesson_content: This step-by-step guide is planned to help players execute a 3/4 piece that has two very contrasting parts, one that is very lineal and melodic, other that is relatively fast and to be played with a very active attitude. As well as that, the end goal piece have two alternatives fingerings to perform, one on 1st position and the other that includes 3rd position. We recommend the player to first focus on playing the entire piece on 1st position. Only after this goal is reached, the learners can move on to the next challenge, which is to use the fingerings indicated on the score.

lessons.lesson_title: D Dorian Scale – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

D Dorian is a modal scale rather than a tonal scale. Scales like this were more used in medieval times and in early music. After that they have been borrowed time to time by classical musicians and came back to use only in the beginning of 20th century. Pay attention to the color of this scale, it does sound a bit minor and a bit major at the same time!
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12181/3645 D Dorian Scale.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – C Major 3/4 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Arpeggiating a chord can sound very melodic and can be a bit demanding as well. If performing this exercise is too hard for you, try to play each note twice and thrice before going for the actual line. These sort of repetitions give you chance to relax and rapidly prepare the next note.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12139/3696 Left Hand Workout - C Major 34.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Broken 3rds – C Major – 2 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Broken 3rds are a big part of classical music vocabulary. While playing them slow; preparing the string change not only from the hands but also from both elbows can help the learner to speed up. In faster tempos the elbows should be positioned to stand rihgt in between position required to play the two strings.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12138/3697 Broken 3rds - C Major - 2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Stacattos in 3/4 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise requires very slow practice at the beginning. Try to start each note after the bow’s point of contact is well established on the string. Only then with a rapid and clear beginning begin the bow stroke. The right hand can get relaxed right after the start, instead of staying stiff. The ending needs to be stopped but not muted on the string. Start playing the next note only after establishing a good position to begin. This will become easier and faster only in time.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12137/3698 Bow Workout - Stacattos in 34.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – Staccatos With String Change in 3/4 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

String crossing while playing staccato is actually not that hard once string change combination is cleared out. It is recommended to play this line once without staccato to achieve this comfort level, after that applying the staccato technique described in other staccatto exercises on it must be easier.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12136/3699 Bow Workout - Staccatos With String Change In 3 4.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12136/3699 Bow Workout - Stacattos With String Change in 34.xml

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Scale Starting on A String (3rd Position) – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

While playing on higher positions, players must be careful about their left thumb; it needs to follow their index finger precisely to the point of the position. Once the hand position is correct, getting used to slightly smaller intervals is not going to be that hard. The note D can be compared to the open string D to make sure the intonation is well at the start point. Same trick is recommended to check if A is in tune as well.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12135/3700 D Major Scale Starting On A String (3Rd Position).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12135/3700 D Major Scale Starting on A String (3rd Position).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Position Changes 1 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When playing scales or melodies on position, if the learner is new to playing in higher positions, it is recommended to play the same content one octave below or if possible, as is on the 1st position. This way the ear figures out what needs to be done, and most often fingers follow that. While sliding to the new position, player can move the pivot finger (marked with smaller notes) on the string but should not press it down.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12134/3701 Case Specific - Position Changes 1.xml

course_content:
Highlights

  • Introduction to fundamental techniques.
  • Basic melodic arpeggios.
  • Parallel thirds in open position.
  • Treatment of voices.

Description

With this guitar method you are able to experience Scorewind's didactic approach to music for free! We hope you appreciate the "step by step" model we have developed. If so, we welcome you to enrol in the other music methods we have available for you. Have fun! By the end of the steps within this method you will encounter an etude by Fernando Sor which presents some of the fundamental techniques necessary to know how to play the classical guitar. It introduces melodic arpeggios, parallel thirds in open position, and basic voicing treatment.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the guitar fretboard)
  • Proficiency in maintaining stable tempo on a 4/4 bar.
  • Familiar with playing two notes at the same time.
  • Novice level of using the 4th finger.

What's next

Next course: Getting Familiar With Melodic Arpeggios and Thirds
course_short_description: With this guitar method you will be able to experience Scorewind's didactic 'step by step' approach to music for free! It introduces melodic arpeggios, parallel thirds in open position, and basic voicing treatment.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Guitar Method (Demo): First Position Foundations’
lessons.lesson_content:
With this guitar method you are able to experience Scorewind's didactic approach to music for free! We hope you appreciate the "step by step" model we have developed. If so, we welcome you to enrol in the other music methods we have available for you. Have fun!

By the end of the steps within this method you will encounter an etude by Fernando Sor which presents some of the fundamental techniques necessary to know how to play the classical guitar. It introduces melodic arpeggios, parallel thirds in open position, and basic voicing treatment.

lessons.lesson_title: C major Scale in First Position One Octave – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Practicing this scale will give you a better sense of the melodic and harmonic context of the music. It will help your fingers to memorize the place of the notes on the instrument, as well as strengthening them.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12119/3731 C Major Scale in First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Scale in First Position One Octave – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Practice this scale to get familiar with the notes that you will use on the piece. Follow the fingerings given by the score, paying special attention to the coordination between the second and third fingers when playing on the first string.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12118/3732 G Major Scale in First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Scale of Available Notes in First Position – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

On this exercise you will play through all the available notes of the scale present on the piece, from its lowest to its highest note. It will help you gain full control of the note spectrum of the music, and improve the coordination of your both hands.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12117/12117 3733 All Available Notes C Major Scale.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12117/3733 Scale of Available Notes in First Position (C major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: C Major Arpeggio in First Position – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

By practicing arpeggios you will be working on the melodic and intervallic patterns of the music. C major arpeggio and chord on the first position usually requires special attention to the horizontal extension of the left hand fingers 3-2-1.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12116/3734 C Major Arpeggio in First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: D Minor Arpeggio in First Position – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This arpeggio will help you workout the vertical placement of fingers 3-2-4, which can sometimes be a difficult combination. Make sure that the 4th finger is curved and aligned with the 3rd finger.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12115/3735 D Minor Arpeggio.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Arpeggio on First Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This arpeggio will help you get familiar with the technical challenge of the vertical extension of the second and third finger. The pressed notes of this arpeggio also give you the fingering for playing the G major chord on the first position.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12114/3736 G Major Arpeggio in First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Open Broken Thirds in First Position – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise will help you to get familiar with the technical challenges over the vertical finger extensions existing in this type of intervals. Make sure to feel comfortable playing them, because they often appear throughout the music of this era.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12113/3737 G major open broken thirds in first position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Open Parallel Thirds on First Position – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

The technical arpeggio p-m, i, is one of the most common styles of playing in this music genre, and together with open thirds they have made some of the most wonderful music for guitar. Pay attention to keep the legato between the notes, and a stable and rounded right hand.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12111/3739 G Major Open Parallel Thirds on First Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Difficult Intervals – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In the following exercise you will be focusing on individual intervals present on the piece which tend to be uncomfortable for the left hand. If you have practiced the arpeggios on the previous steps, this exercise might be easier for you to play.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12112/3738 Case Specific - Difficult Intervals.xml

course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing a melody with large syncopation between bars.
  • Executing melodies with dotted note content.

Description

This course contains preparation material that will lead the player to perform Dancla's Etude No. 9, Op. 84 successfully. The vocabulary of the piece itself is very similar to some other etudes of his, but this one comes with more dotted rhythm challenges, and a large syncopation at the middle section. Syncopation means running over the beat with a note that starts in the middle of the previous beat, if this sounds complicated, we trust our score viewer will help you understand it!

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Mobility of 2nd and 3rd fingers.
  • Proficiency in using 4th finger.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.
  • Proficiency in slurring 2 to 4 notes in one bow evenly.

What's next

Next course: Starting with Minor Pieces
course_short_description: This course contains preparation material that will lead the player to perform successfully the rhythmic challenges of Dancla's Etude No. 9, Op. 84.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘First Steps Towards Rhythmic Challenges’
lessons.lesson_content: This course contains preparation material that will lead the player to perform Dancla's Etude No. 9, Op. 84 successfully. The vocabulary of the piece itself is very similar to some other etudes of his, but this one comes with more dotted rhythm challenges, and a large syncopation at the middle section. Syncopation means running over the beat with a note that starts in the middle of the previous beat, if this sounds complicated, we trust our score viewer will help you understand it!

lessons.lesson_title: G Major 2 Octave Scale with Slurs of 4 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Practicing this scale both with open strings and with 4th finger instead can be useful. Try to use the entire bow divided into four equal parts for learning how to use the bow economically. The finger pattern does not stay symmetrical and it is good to be aware of that.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12179/3647 12179 G Major 2 Octave Scale With Slurs of 4.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12179/3647 G Major 2 Octave Scale with Slurs of 4.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Broken 3rds – D Major 2 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Broken 3rds are a big part of classical music vocabulary. While playing them slow; preparing the string change from both elbows can help the learner to speed up. In faster tempos both elbows should be held in a posture positioned in the middle of the angles necessary to play both strings individually to move as less as possible.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12149/3685 Broken 3rds - D Major 2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Rhytmic Workout – Syncopation 1 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by the ScoreWind Teachers

Syncopation can come in many forms and this is one of the most common patterns. In its repetitive form the bow strokes shift from a down stroke starting pattern to an up stroke pattern. Accenting the second note of each group can emphasise the placement shift and bring out the syncopation more clearly.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12148/3686 12148 Rhythmic Workout - Syncopation 1.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Rhytmic Workout – Syncopation 2 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing this exercise requires a lot of mind work. Dividing the beat to 8th notes in mind and always remembering where the down beat is (which is always in the middle of a note that is being played, so it is hidden from the player) can be frustrating, but accenting each off beat will help gaining control over this lack of visible strong beat.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12147/3687 12147 Rhythmic Workout - Syncopation 2.xml

course_title: Flow of One Single Melody Line
course_content:
Highlights

  • Single melody voice treatment.
  • Right hand’s index-middle finger workout.
  • Ascending and descending scales.
  • Thumb and bass line practice.
  • Broad arpeggios.
  • Broken thirds.
  • Octave technique.
  • Jump to fifth position during a scale.

Description

This step by step method will help to practice an etude by Fernando Sor. The specialty of this etude is that it consists of a single melody line from beginning to end of the piece. Sor's musical talent finds a way to make the guitar sound with its usual full bodied sound, even though there isn't a supporting bass line or an acompaniment. Here you will practice fast and long scales, broad arpeggios, broken thirds, as well as getting introduced to the challenging octave technique. One of the hardest challenges of this etude is the position change happening during a scale, in which you would use the open e string to have a reliable jump.

Requirement

  • Beginner-intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Proficiency in keeping stable tempo on a ternary pulse.
  • Proficiency in melodic arpeggios.
  • Novice level in broken thirds.
  • Beginner level in scale practice.
  • Familiar in playing with the thumb.

What's next

Next course: Scales, Arpeggios and Flowing Bass Lines!
course_short_description: This step by step method will help to practice an etude by Fernando Sor. The specialty of this etude is that it consists of a single melody line from beginning to end of the piece. Sor's musical talent finds a way to make the guitar sound with its usual full bodied sound, even though there isn't a supporting bass line, or acompaniment.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Flow of One Single Melody Line”
lessons.lesson_content: This step by step method will help to practice an etude by Fernando Sor. The specialty of this etude is that it consists of a single melody line from beginning to end of the piece. Sor’s musical talent finds a way to make the guitar sound with its usual full bodied sound, even though there isn’t a supporting bass line or an acompaniment. Here you will practice fast and long scales, broad arpeggios, broken thirds, as well as getting introduced to the challenging octave technique. One of the hardest challenges of this etude is the position change happening during a scale, in which you would use the open e string to have a reliable jump.

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Scale With 1st to 5th Position Jump
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

There are times when the scale you want to play requires that you make long position changes. This can interrupt the flow your your scale, leading you to not play legato, or press notes wrongly, resulting in a noise. The best way to make position changes during scales is to use the moment you reach to an open string note. Since you're not pressing any note at that moment, your hand is free to move to the next position, without interrupting the sound. Thus, when you reach to the open E on the first string, you'll  use that moment to drag your 3rd finger from D to F# on the second string. That way you successfully transfer your hand from the 1st to the 5th position.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12095/12095 3772 G Major Scale With Position Change From 1Th To 5Th.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12095/3772 G Major Scale with change from 1st to 5th position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: A Major Arpeggio on 1st Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

To successfuly play the A major arpeggio on first position, you must work on the flowing movement of your left hand. The notes of this chord are so tightly packed throughout the second fret, that you will have to adapt your hand placement both at the beginning and the end of the arpeggio in order to reach well to the low C on the 5th string and the high A on the 1st string. The secret for a good change is to let your 4th finger lead your hand as you both go up and down through the notes.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12094/3773 A Major Arpeggio.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Ascending Broken Thirds in a Descending G major Scale
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Ascending broken thirds are typically used throughout the guitar's Classical Romantic period. By making sure that you have this technique under control, you will be promoting a much quicker learning of new repertoire, since it won't be an unworked challenge for you anymore. Pay attention to not repeat fingers on your left hand as that will disrupt the amazing flow of this type of passage.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12093/12093 3774 Ascending Broken Thirds In A Descending G Major Scale.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12093/3774 Ascending Broken Thirds in a Descending G major scale.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Octave Technique in G Major Scale on 1st Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

As you grow as a classical guitarist and you learn more about the classical romantic repertoire of Sor, Giuliani, Carcassi, Legnani, and others, you will be playing some of the most virtuoso music ever written for the instrument. Octavation of a scale is one of the most aclaimed techniques of this era. The etude on this method already introduces it to you, in a very friendly and accessible context. Practice it right, and you will have created a solid ground to continue developing this incredible technique.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12043/12043 3829 Octave Technique In G Major Scale.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12043/12043 3829 Octave Technique in G Major Scale.xml

course_title: Get Better at Slurred String Changes
course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing chromatic musical lines.
  • Controlling string crossings with efficient elbow moves.

Description

The end goal of this step-by-step guide is to play a lovely Valse that has a very bright and bittersweet melody, and exercises leading to it will give every player the comfort to execute the piece as delicately as it needs to be. The melody contains quite a few string crossings and a bit of chromatism but they are all reachable goals for a person that gained experience over valse rhythm, slurring notes and G major melodies.

Requirement

  • Proficiency in 3/4 time signature.
  • Mobility of left hand for diagonal shapes (rapid shifts or maintaining intervals between strings).
  • Swift string crossing abilities.
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.

What's next

Next course: Perfect Your Classical Music Phrasing
course_short_description: The end goal of this step-by-step guide is to play a lovely Valse that has a very bright and bittersweet melody, and exercises leading to it will give every player the comfort to execute the piece as delicately as it needs to be.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Get Better at Slurred String Changes’
lessons.lesson_content: The end goal of this step-by-step guide is to play a lovely Valse that has a very bright and bittersweet melody, and exercises leading to it will give every player the comfort to execute the piece as delicately as it needs to be. The melody contains quite a few string crossings and a bit of chromatism but they are all reachable goals for a person that gained experience over valse rhythm, slurring notes and G major melodies.

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – Speeding up Fingers (C Major) – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

While playing this exercise players must be careful about tilting the bow so the hair faces the player near the frog, and straightening the bow to widen the point of contact towars the tip. Meanwhile, the left elbow should be relaxedly hanging from the hand and left hand fingers can optionally hammer each note.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12133/3702 Left Hand Workout - Speeding Up Fingers (C Major).mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12133/3702 Left Hand Workout - Speeding up Fingers (C Major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – String Crossing – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This is a good exercise to gain awareness about how much bow is used and when during playing various lenghts. Long notes should not be played in a way that they finish the bow, there needs to be at least a 3rd of the left for the last beat. Because when string cross happens at the tip of the bow the maneuver can be done only by the front arm.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12132/3703 Case Specific - String Crossing.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – String Crossing 3 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This a little “out of the ordinary” pattern is good to coordinate the right hand. Remembering that string crossing is a vertical move rather than horizontal can be helpful to leave a good amount of bow for the long note that will follow the string crossing.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12131/3704 Case Specific - String Crossing 3.xml

course_title: Get Better at String Crossing Melodiously
course_content:
Highlights

  • Ending phrases with a decrescendo.
  • Controlling string crossings with efficient elbow moves.
  • Learning the tension-resolution sound of dominant and tonic chords.

Description

This course prepares the learner to play a melodic etude by Dancla from his book of 36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84. Each step leads the player to gain ease at the tonality, the rhythmic content and the specific challenges the player has to achieve successfully to play the piece with comfort and joy.

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Proficiency in half and quarter notes.
  • Mobility of 2nd finger. (to switch between 1-23 / 12-3 hand positions)

What's next

Next course: Learn to Perform Musical Phrases Clearly
course_short_description: This course prepares you to play an etude by Dancla from '36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84'. Each step will lead you to gain ease at the tonality, the rhythmic content and the specific challenges to play the piece with comfort and joy.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Get Better at String Crossing Melodiously’
lessons.lesson_content: This course prepares the learner to play a melodic etude by Dancla from his book of 36 Easy and Melodic Studies, Op. 84. Each step leads the player to gain ease at the tonality, the rhythmic content and the specific challenges the player has to achieve successfully to play the piece with comfort and joy.

lessons.lesson_title: Bow Workout – String Crossing 2
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise should be carried on with a very slow and careful bow stroke. One must remember that crossing the string can be a vertical move rather than a horizontal move that in this case is mainly done by the front arm, meaning the right elbow does not need to move much. Make sure to twist the bow for the hair to face the player when approaching the frog while playing up bow, and twist the palm back towards the floor while playing down bow.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12167/3663 Bow Workout - String Crossing 2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: C Major Scale – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing the scale of the music piece is a very healthy workout for keeping the intonation clean from the first place. While playing C Major in this octave, the learner can use open strings or 4th finger, but the main goal is to realize and carry out the nearness of the 1st and 2nd fingers. The two fingers should touch each other rather than having a gap in between.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12190/3634 C Major Scale.xml

lessons.lesson_title: C Major Arpeggio and Inversions – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Various inversions starting from C are good for getting used to certain interval jumps and to reassure the tonal center. Players can prepare the finger position of the next note while playing the current note. This way of thinking can be applied to the string crossings as well.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12174/3654 C Major Arpeggio and Inversions.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Available notes in 1st position – C Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Available notes of a key on a violin’s certain position is very essential in cases where we play a piece that is in a key but goes above or below the general scale that we are used to play. This way we learn the correct pitch of notes of the key outside the field that the scale limits us to. For the curious ones: this practice system is commonly used in the Galamian method.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12177/3651 12177 Available Notes In 1St Position C Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12177/3651 Available notes in 1st position - C Major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Open String Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise is eliminating the notes of the introduction phrase by making the string crossings the one and only challenge to face. One can play it without slurs first just to get the string cross coordination right, and then introduce the slurs the piece indicates. You can apply this way of practice to all hard passages you encounter, omit the challenge of the left hand to focus on the right hand.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12166/3664 Case Specific - Open String Exercise.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Open String Exercise 2
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise is eliminating the notes of the second half of the introduction phrase by making the string crossings the one and only challenge to face. One can play it without slurs first just to get the string cross coordination right, and then introduce the slurs the piece indicates. This practice technique is recommended to apply to other passages as well.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12165/3665 Case Specific - Open String Exercise 2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Intonation Workout – Semitones on E String
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

To play a semitone in the 1st position, on most violins, one must feel the nail of the previous finger over the tip of the next finger. This tension can sound harsh in the beginning but if the second note is “aimed”, the resolution comes out and it sounds lovely. Make sure that your left elbow is not near your chest but rather pointing away from your body.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12164/3666 12164 Intonation Workout Semitones on E String.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12164/3666 Intonation Workout - Semitones on E String.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Intonation Workout – G Dominant Chord
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

From a harmonic perspective, this chord may sound surprising to learners of the violin. The tension that happens between the notes B and F needs to be realized for tuning it well. The diagonal relation of the 2nd and 1st finger is an essential workout for fine tuning the pitch. To tune them well on most violins the fingers would be so close that they could pushing each other.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12163/3671 Intonation Workout - G Dominant Chord.xml

course_content:
Highlights

  • Executing long lasting phrases that include fast bow strokes.
  • Playing eight note runs.
  • Learning to play long phrases that include slurs.
  • Learning to extend the 3rd finger to gain 12-34 hand position.

Description

This method uses a step-by-step guide prepared by the ScoreWind teachers to introduce the players to slurring longer passages than 2 notes. Goal piece at the end of the workout exercises is a wonderful musical piece, Number 5 from the Melodic Studies op.84 by C. Dancla. Although the name indicates serious practice, the pieces in this book have a lovely classical musical quality!

Requirement

  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the violin fretboard)
  • Proficiency in half, quarter, eight and dotted notes.
  • Mobility of 2nd finger. (to switch between 1-23 / 12-3 hand positions)
  • Proficiency in using 4th finger.
  • Proficiency in slurring 2 to 4 notes in one bow evenly.

What's next

Next course: Become Better at Long Lasting 8th Note Phrases
course_short_description: This method uses a step-by-step guide prepared by the ScoreWind teachers to introduce the players to slurring longer passages than 2 notes. At the end of the exercises you will play Etude N. 5, Op.84 by C. Dancla.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to ‘Get Fluent at Slurring 4 Notes’
lessons.lesson_content: This method uses a step-by-step guide prepared by the ScoreWind teachers to introduce the players to slurring longer passages than 2 notes. Goal piece at the end of the workout exercises is a wonderful musical piece, Number 5 from the Melodic Studies op.84 by C. Dancla. Although the name indicates serious practice, the pieces in this book have a lovely classical musical quality!

lessons.lesson_title: Available notes in 1st position – D Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Normally when you hear something in D major you can often hear something starting in D, or maybe from A. It is exactly the point of this scale to start from the lowest possible note you can get on the violin that belongs to the scale of D major. This means that our first note will be the low G. This “taking you out of the traditional perception of tonality” helps you to learn what each pitch really sounds like. On a more technical end, make sure your elbows follow each other parallelly as you go up and down the scale.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13489/3649 13489 Available Notes in 1st Position D Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13489/3649 Available notes in 1st position - D Major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Intonation Workout – Open String Checking for D Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this exercise the player gains confidence on placing the notes correctly, with or without the previous notes placed on the fingerboard. Hearing the open strings can train the ear and tune one’s ear to the tonal center. Using 4th finger is not necessary but recommended. When placing 2nd or 3rd finger, imagining the placement of the previous fingers can help.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12156/3678 12156 Intonation Workout Open String Checking for D Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12156/3678 Intonation Workout - Open String Checking for D Major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Available notes in 1st position – G Major – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Available notes of a key on a violin’s certain position is very essential in cases where we play a piece that is in a key but goes above or below the general scale that we are used to play. This way we learn the correct pitch of notes of the key outside the field that the scale limits us to.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12178/3648 12178 Available Notes in 1st Position G Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12178/3648 Available notes in 1st position - G Major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – Speeding up Fingers (G Major) – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When playing this exercise learners must remember that the bow stroke is a simple long bow stroke and keep the left hand fingers as round as possible for precision of timing the 8th notes. Although hammering each note may not be necessary it can be useful to gain strength. Make sure to not press the strings to the fingerboard more than necessary. The tip of the finger and nail should not go all white but stay clear.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12154/3680 12155 Left Hand Workout Speeding up Fingers G Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12154/3680 Left Hand Workout - Speeding up Fingers (G Major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Left Hand Workout – Speeding up Fingers (D Major) – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

It is important to remember that the bow stroke in this exercise is a simple long bow stroke, and the amount of notes played on it has no effect on how that movement goes. The left hand fingers must be as round as possible for precision of timing the 8th notes. Although hammering each note may not be necessary, it can be useful to gain strength. Make sure to not press the strings to the fingerboard more than necessary. The tip of the finger and nail should not go all white.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12155/3679 12155 Left Hand Workout Speeding up Fingers D Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12155/3679 Left Hand Workout - Speeding up Fingers (D Major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Scale with Slurs of 4 – Violin Exercise
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

When playing this exercise, try to use the entire bow divided into four equal parts for learning how to use the bow economically. String changes can be prepared while playing the last notes of the slur. Make sure to tilt the bow near the frog and straighten it towards the tip to have an even sounding bow stroke.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12180/3646 12180 D Major Scale with Slurs of 4.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12180/3646 D Major Scale with Slurs of 4.xml

course_title: Getting Familiar With Melodic Arpeggios and Thirds
course_content:
Highlights

  • Ascending and descending melodic arpeggios.
  • Slow to fast rhythmic challenges.
  • Closed and open broken thirds.

Description

This step by step method will help you practice an etude composed by Fernando Sor, with which you can explore ascending and descending melodic arpeggios, slow to fast rhythmic challenges, as well as both closed and open broken thirds.

Requirement

  • Completion of course: ‘First Position Fondations’.
  • Novice level of score reading ability. (slow but steady deciphering skills for the notes that coincide 1st position on the guitar fretboard)
  • Proficiency in quarter and eight notes.
  • Novice level of using the 4th finger.
  • Beginner level in left hand vertical finger extension.

What's next

Next course: Introduction to Chords and Arpeggios
course_short_description: This step by step method will help you practice an etude composed by Fernando Sor, with with you can explore ascending and descending melodic arpeggios, slow to fast rhythmic challenges, as well as both closed and open broken thirds.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Getting Familiar With Melodic Arpeggios and Thirds”
lessons.lesson_content: This step by step method will help you practice an etude composed by Fernando Sor, with which you can explore ascending and descending melodic arpeggios, slow to fast rhythmic challenges, as well as both closed and open broken thirds.

lessons.lesson_title: G Major Scale in First Position Two Octaves
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Practice this scale to get familiar with the notes that you will use on the piece. Follow the fingerings given by the score, paying special attention to the coordination between the second and third fingers when playing on the first string.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12110/12110 3740 G Major Scale 2 Octaves First Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12110/3740 G Major Scale in First Position (2 octaves).xml

lessons.lesson_title: Open Single Strings Speed and Rhythm – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this exercise you will focus on the speed and coordination of you i-m, and m-i throughout the six strings. The short speed bursts are meant to teach your fingers to play faster and keep stability in quick changes between slower and faster rhythm.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12109/3741 Open Single Strings Speed and Rhythm.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 1 – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this step you can work the good positioning of your right hand, because p-i-m-a arpeggios require a stable and rounded placement of hand and fingers. Changing between strings, as given in the exercise, will add an extra level of challenge to keep that stability.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12108/3742 Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 1.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Open Broken Thirds All Available Notes of  C major – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise will help you to get familiar with the technical challenges over the vertical finger extensions existing in this type of intervals. Make sure to feel comfortable playing them, because they often appear throughout the music of this era.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13547/13547 3743 Broken Open Thirds All Available Notes C Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13547/3743 Open Broken Thirds All Available Notes of C major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Close Broken Thirds in G major – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Close thirds do not require large finger extensions, as the open thirds usually do, but they often bring uncomfortable finger placement, and challenging finger independence for the left hand. Practice carefully this exercise and the thirds of the music piece will become easier for you.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13548/13548 3744 Broken Close Thirds G Major Start On D.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13548/13548 3744 Broken Close Thirds G Major Start On D.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Finger Independency in Intervals – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In the following exercise you will be focusing on intervals changes that might might be challenging in the piece. Your main focus should be to teach your fingers exactly where they should go, keeping a good legato and volume balance.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12107/12107 3745 Case Specific Etude 1 Op 44 Sor Focus On Passage.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12107/3745 Case Specific - Finger Independency in Intervals.xml

course_content:
Highlights

  • Focus on melody/harmonic treatment.
  • Left hand’s movement in chord blocks.
  • Right hand flow through technical arpeggios.

Description

Explore essential chords and arpeggios in this step by step method ideal for beginner players. In this etude the arpeggios have a more harmonic treatment, even though the intervals are also the melody of the piece. The goal is to move the left hand fingers in blocks of chords, while keeping a flowing movement of the right hand fingers through the strings to play the arpeggio.

Requirement

  • Completion of course: ‘Getting Familiar With Melodic Arpeggios and Thirds’
  • Novice level of score reading ability.
  • Beginner level in right hand arpeggiation.
  • Beginner level in using the right hand’s ring finger (a)
  • Stable tempo, and stable 8th notes on 2/4 bars.
  • Beginner level in left hand vertical finger extension.

What's next

Next course: Classical Homophony and Arpeggiation
course_short_description: Explore essential guitar chords and arpeggios in this step by step method ideal for beginner players. The etude by Fernando Sor focuses on the harmonic treatment of arpeggios. The main goal is to develop the right hand arpeggio technique.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Introduction to Chords and Arpeggios”
lessons.lesson_content: Explore essential chords and arpeggios in this step by step method ideal for beginner players. In this etude the arpeggios have a more harmonic treatment, even though the intervals are also the melody of the piece. The goal is to move the left hand fingers in blocks of chords, while keeping a flowing movement of the right hand fingers through the strings to play the arpeggio.

lessons.lesson_title: D Dominant Arpeggio in First Position with La Extention
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This arpeggio might be challenging at first, for your fingers have to spread through the frets so that the 4th finger reaches well to the mid Fa# and the high La. Pay attention to the different sonority of this arpeggio as you reach to do, the 7th note that gives the dominant aspect to the chord.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12106/12106 3747 D Dominant Arpeggio With A Extension.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12106/3747 D Dominant Arpeggio in First Position with La Extention.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 2 – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

In this step you can practice a chord change present on the piece while playing through its way of arpeggiating. In this case you need to have full control of your 'p-i, a, m' combination, and keep a precise rhythm.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12105/12105 3748 Case Specifit R H Arpeggio Technique 1.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12105/3748 Case Specific - Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 1.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 3 – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This exercise follow the same harmonic structure as the previous step, and the goal is also to gain control over the arpeggiation of the notes with the right hand, as well as getting familiar with this chord change, so common in that period.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12104/3749 Case Specific - Arpeggio Right Hand Technique 2.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Broken Sixths in first position in C Major – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Like the broken thirds, passages of intervals of sixths are pretty common in this music style. This exercise is ideal for the coordination of the fingers of the left hand, and for gaining control over playing with thumb-index, or thumb-middle, fingers of the right hand.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12103/12103 3750 Broken Sixths In First Position In C Major.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12103/3750 Broken Sixths in first position in C Major.xml

course_content:
Highlights

  • D major foundations.
  • Second position playing.
  • Ballance and use of all left hand fingers.
  • Broad scales, arpeggios, homophonic voicing, single slurs.
  • Thumb and bass line practice.

Description

This step by step method will help you building the foudantions for playing pieces in D major. Playing a piece in this tonality means that you will be practicing second position fingerings. It can be more challenging than playing in first position, because you have less access to open strings, which would help the left hand. Now you will be using in a constant your four fingers (1, 2, 3, 4), and here the secret for a good hand position is to make sure that your 4th finger is always near the fretboard, and horizontally aligned with your 1st finger. Specifically with this etude by Fernando Sor, you will practice scales of a broad range, homophonic voicings, arpeggios, single slurs, position changes, and fast flowing basslines.

Requirement

  • Beginner-intermediate level of score reading ability.
  • Beginner level in position changes.
  • Proficiency in 1st position scales.
  • Proficiency in the fast exchange between index and middle fingers (i,m).
  • Proficiency in stable left hand and control of all four fingers.
  • Comfortable with two parallel voice leading.
course_short_description: This step by step method will help you build the foudantions for playing in D major. Playing in this tonality means that you will be practicing second position fingerings. This tonality workout includes scales of a broad range, homophonic voicings, arpeggios, single slurs, position changes, and fast flowing basslines.

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to “Introduction to D Major Fingerings”
lessons.lesson_content: This step by step method will help you building the foudantions for playing pieces in D major. Playing a piece in this tonality means that you will be practicing second position fingerings. It can be more challenging than playing in first position, because you have less access to open strings, which would help the left hand. Now you will be using in a constant your four fingers (1, 2, 3, 4), and here the secret for a good hand position is to make sure that your 4th finger is always near the fretboard, and horizontally aligned with your 1st finger. Specifically with this etude by Fernando Sor, you will practice scales of a broad range, homophonic voicings, arpeggios, single slurs, position changes, and fast flowing basslines.

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Scale on Second Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Playing D major scale on second position frees you from always having to play on the first position. Allow space between your left hand fingers and keep them horizontally aligned. Make use of the open strings to help you through this scale. If you want to go to the next level of difficulty, we suggest you practice it without any open strings. That will greatly improve the strength and agility of your left hand, as well as giving you a fingering model of a major scale that can be applied to any position of the fretboard. (Yes! No matter where you start your scale, if you play this same fingering without the open strings, it will always be a major scale!)
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12092/12092 3776 D Major Scale on Second Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12092/3776 D Major Scale in Second Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Scale of Available Notes of D Major on 2nd Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

This scale gives you the whole spectrum of notes that you can play of a D major scale on the second position. Make use of the open strings to help you play through the scale. Keep your left hand fingers horizontally aligned, and allow plenty of space between themselves. That solid hand disposition will promote stability and increase your speed.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12091/12091 3777 Scale of Available Notes of D Major on 2nd Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12091/3777 Scale of Available Notes (D major).xml

lessons.lesson_title: D Major Arpeggio on Second Position
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

Keep your left hand fingers rounded and always prepared right on top of each fret. If you directly play this arpeggio from the 2nd position, you won't have to be jumping between 1st to 2nd position. You can choose to play the low D on the 5th string, as that will give you the fingering model to play a major arpeggio enywhere on the fretboard.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12090/12090 3778 D Major Arpeggio on Second Position.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12090/3778 D Major Arpeggio in Second Position.xml

lessons.lesson_title: A Dominant Arpeggio
lessons.lesson_content:
A Dominant Arpeggio

This arpeggio is very similar with the A Major one, but here we add the 7th note of the chord, G natural; that turns the arpeggio into an A Dominant chord. You can use the G in the open third string to change your hand position as you play through the low to high registers of the arpeggio and back again to the low notes. This is a wide range arpeggio, therefore you have to find the right balance between finger extension and minor to major elbow and wrist adjustments. Throughout the video you will see how different the arm and hand look as I play in the low-mid-high registers.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13516/13516 A Dominant Arpeggio.xml

lessons.lesson_title: E Major Arpeggio – Guitar Exercises
lessons.lesson_content:
by ScoreWind Teachers

E major arpeggio on first position is one of the most full bodied chords for the guitar. The 4-2-3 finger extention on the low notes can be quite challenging, so make sure you get used to opening as much as possible your left hand fingers. You can play with the flow movement of your hand to support the adjustment of the 4th finger in both low and high G#'s.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet12089/3780 E Major Arpeggio.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Rhythm and Subdivision Workout
lessons.lesson_content:
Rhythm and Subdivision Workout

In this exercise you get to practice various subdivisions of the beat. We will always play the same note (D on fourth string), but we will progressively change it from quarter notes, to eighth notes, to sixteenth notes, and ending on a single half note. Besides caring about the precision of the subdivision and keeping the beat, you can focus on the exchange of your right hand fingers. You can do this exercise with the index-middle fingers only, but I would like to invite you to practice with every finger combination, and in the following order: m-i; i-a; a-i; a-m; m-a; (i-index; m-middle; a-ring finger or “anular”).
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13519/13519 Rhythm and Subdivision Workout.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Slurred Appoggiaturas
lessons.lesson_content:
Slurred Appoggiaturas

Here you will practice slurred appoggiaturas with every single finger (1, 2, 3, 4), linking the slur to the open first string. In order to sound like an appoggiatura, the slur must be played really fast, like a small decoration on top of the main note, which is the open E. The slur must be clear. Don’t pull with too much strength, nor hit the fingerboard with your finger. That will make it sound dirty. Find the midpoint between releasing and pulling the string in order to reach a good sounding slur.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13521/13521 Slurred Appoggiaturas.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Extensions in Fast Passages
lessons.lesson_content:
Case Specific - Extensions in Fast Passages

In this exercise you have the chance to prepare yourself to play one of the hard passages of the piece. Take all the time you need before venturing into the piece. Speed and extensions are the two elements that together create this challenging passage. I recommend you to scan your posture note by note, and  find the places that will help your fingers the most. Your knuckles are the reference; are they too far or too close from the note you’re pressing? Adjusting your shoulder, elbow and wrist will certainly help you have a well rounded hand that can easily run through the passage.
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13523/13523 Case Specific - Extensions In Fast Passages.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13523/13523 Case Specific - Extensions in Fast Passages.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Parallel Thirds in D Major
lessons.lesson_content:
Parallel Thirds in D Major

The most effective way to master this exercise is to make sure you keep your fingers prepared at all times. This means that each one of your fingers will be “floating” just above each of the four frets you will be using (from 2nd to 5th fret). This is most important when you’re playing in the low registers. If it is too tiring for your hand to stay wide open through the whole exercise, you can relax it once you reach the first two strings. That window will allow you to regain the strength you need to finish the exercise with a good hand.
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13526/13526 Parallel Thirds in D Major.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Introduction to Barre of Two and Three Strings
lessons.lesson_content:
Introduction to Barre of Two and Three Strings

It is possible that you will be making your very first barré with this exercise; meaning that you will be pressing more than one string with just your first finger. Barrés can be done by pressing all the 6 strings with the index, but you can have smaller barrés, such as the two and three strings barrés. Because this is just an introduction exercise, we will only be practicing the barrés of two and three strings. The pressure must be even between the strings you’re pressing. Make sure that every note sounds clean. If this is not the case, you must find a different way to place your finger. Check out the video for the visual reference!
lessons.lesson_video: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13527/13527 Introduction To Barre Of Two And Three Strings.mp4
lessons.lesson_score_viewer: https://scorewind.com/sw-music/pdfProject/Sheet13527/13527 Introduction to Barre of Two and Three Strings.xml

lessons.lesson_title: Case Specific – Divide Hard Passage 1
lessons.lesson_content:
Case Specific - Divide Hard Passage 1

The more we practice a piece, the more we get to know it, but there are of course different ways of practicing and how to approach a specific difficult passage.
